Fig 5 Two-dimensional metalloporphyrin-based covalent organic frameworks as bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR: A computational study Xinyang Liu Writing – original draft Investigation ‡ Donghui Zhang Software Methodology Investigation ‡ Jingwei Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Gang Li Resources Funding acquisition Jingxiang Zhao Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, and Key Laboratory of Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, Harbin Normal University, Harbin 150025, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Key Laboratory of Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials Ministry of Education Harbin Normal University Harbin 150025 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, and Key Laboratory of Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, Harbin Normal University, Harbin 150025, China ⁎ Corresponding author. ‡ These authors contributed equally to this work. Metalloporphyrin-based covalent organic frameworks (COFs) with controllable metal sites and charge densities have become a front research field in catalysis. Herein, through the comprehensive density functional theory (DFT) computations, we explored the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalytic activities on a series of two-dimensional (2D) metalloporphyrin-based graphdiyne analogs (TM-PDY, TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, Pt), which are constructed by connecting metal coordinated 5,10,15,20-tetra-(4-phenyl)porphyrin rings and butadiyne. The computations show that Ir- and Rh-PDY can serve as outstanding bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR with ultralow overpotentials (0.45/0.37 and 0.34/0.47 V). The excellent catalytic behaviors are derived from the moderate adsorption interaction of oxygenated species as revealed by the scaling relationships and volcano curves. Remarkably, the adsorption free energies of intermediates are highly related to the electronic structures of TM-PDYs, characterized by the d-band center (ε d), the integrating crystal orbital Hamilton populations (ICOHP), and the universal descriptor φ. Our work not only reveals the OER and ORR catalytic performance of TM-PDYs but also provides an instructive strategy to design catalysts for the energy conversation and storage devices. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Two-dimensional Ir and Rh-PDYs exhibit excellent OER and ORR catalytic activities with low η OER and η ORR (0.45/0.37 and 0.34/0.47 V) and can serve as bifunctional electrocatalysts. Keywords Density functional theory 2D metalloporphyrin-based covalent organic frameworks Single-atom catalysts Bifunctional electrocatalysts Overpotential Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction With the economy booming of modern society, the increasingly serious issues of the global energy crisis and environmental pollution have attracted extensive attention to the development of advanced energy storage and conversion devices, such as fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and electrolytic water [1-9]. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are regarded as two crucial reactions in the green-energy technology [10,11]. However, the high overpotentials and sluggish kinetics in the processes severely restricted the conversion efficiency. Up to now, the commercial electrocatalysts for OER and ORR remain precious-metal-based substances, such as IrO2, RuO2, and Pt-based materials, while the high price and depletable resource hinder their further applications on a large scale [12-14]. The discovery of bifunctional electrocatalysts which can catalyze two reactions at a time is a hot topic, due to the simplified processes and enhanced catalytic efficiency compared to the monofunctional catalysts [15-17]. Hence, further exploring high-performance and inexpensive bifunctional catalysts for OER/ORR is highly desirable. Single-atom catalysts (SACs), synthesized by dispersing isolated metal atoms on the substance [18], have aroused enormous interest as a new research frontier in catalysis owing to the superior catalytic selectivity and improved atomic utilization in comparison with bulk catalysts, which can contribute to saving natural resources and realize atomic economy [19,20]. Recently studies suggested that SACs have successfully catalyzed various kinds of reactions, including hydrogen evolution [21], oxygen evolution [22], oxygen reduction [23], nitrogen fixation [24], carbon dioxide reduction [25], urea electrosynthesis [26], and so on. Metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) catalyst is one kind of SACs and the metal-nitrogen (M-N) units can perform as the catalytic active sites. However, the distribution of M-N active sites is determined by the concentration of carbon defects on the surface of carbon-based material and it is difficult to produce plenty and evenly distributed M-N units of SACs in experiment process. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs), a new family of porous polymers consisting of covalently connected organic molecules, have been applied successfully in gas storage and separation [27], sensors [28], optoelectronics [29,30], catalysis [31] and energy storage [32]. Porphyrins and metalloporphyrins are regarded as one kind of the most ideal building units for the construction of COFs due to stable tetracoordinate environment for metals (M-N4) [33] and tunable charge densities of the active sites [34]. Since first reported by Yaghi [35] and Jiang [36] in 2011, an increasing number of metalloporphyrin-based COFs with abundant and uniformly distributed active sites have been researched for a variety of applications [37-41], especially as catalysts [34,42-45]. For instance, the experiment study showed that the COFs consisting of iron(III) porphyrins exhibit catalytic performance for CO2 reduction to CO with fair Faradaic efficiency and good turnover frequency [43]. Lu et al. reported that Fe-porphyrin-based COFs demonstrated the highest electrocatalytic activities for nitrate reduction, followed by Cu, Ni, and Co [34]. The metalloporphyrin-based GDY analogs (TM-PDY), a 2D porous porphyrin-based COF, can be designed by connecting transition metal atom coordinated 5,10,15,20-tetra-(4-phenyl)porphyrin rings through butadiyne (-CCCC-) of the graphdiyne [46,47]. TM-PDYs present numerous reaction sites and high electron transfer efficiency which are derived from the advantages of metalloporphyrin monomers and butadiyne linkages respectively. Moreover, Co-coordinated porphyrin-based GDY analog (Co-PDY) have been successfully prepared experimentally as high-performance OER catalyst [46]. Theoretical calculation shows that 2D Mo-PDY exhibits excellent electrocatalytic properties for N2 reduction reaction [47]. At present, the OER and ORR catalytic performances of TM-PDY are yet to be investigated. Inspired by the unique structures and rich properties of TM-PDY, we performed comprehensive density functional theory (DFT) to study the OER and ORR catalytic activities on a series of TM-PDY (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, Pt). Our computational results indicate that Ir- and Rh-PDY can serve as outstanding bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR with ultralow overpotentials (0.45/0.37 and 0.34/0.47 V). Since Co-PDY have been synthesized experimentally, 2D TM-PDYs can serve as promising bifunctional catalysts for OER and ORR and can be applied in green-energy related devices. The findings also provide a new approach for designing efficient catalysts. 2 Computational methods All spin-unpolarized and spin-polarized density functional theory DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [48,49] and the projection augmented wave (PAW) method [50,51] pseudopotential was utilized to treat the core electrons. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [52] combined with the Perdew-Burke-Enzehoff (PBE) functional was used to describe the exchange correlation terms with a cutoff energy of 500 eV. The convergence criteria for force and energy were set to 0.05 eV/Å and 1 × 10–4 eV, respectively. The van der Waals (vdW) [53,54] interactions are described using empirical corrections, using the Grimme DFT-D2 method. The original PDY monolayer was placed in the x-y plane while the z-direction is perpendicular to that plane, where a 25 Å vacuum space is set along the z-direction to eliminate possible interactions between adjacent layers. Brillouin regions were sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point-packet grid during geometric optimization. The well-known computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) [55,56] model was used to evaluate the performance of the OER, and ORR and the detailed computing method were shown in Supplementary Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The geometrical structures, stabilities, and electronic properties of the TM-PDY systems Initially, we performed correlative investigations on the geometrical structures, stabilities, and electronic properties of the TM-PDY systems (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, Pt), which is a two dimensional (2D) porous porphyrin-based covalent organic framework (COF) with the rigid square unit of TM-tetracoordinated 5,10,15,20-tetra-(4-phenyl)porphyrin (TPP) [57] rings linked by butadiyne. There are eighty-one atoms in the primitive cell, including fifty-two carbon atoms to construct the skeleton, twenty-four hydrogen atoms to saturate dangling bonds, four pyrrole nitrogen atoms, and one metal atom (Fig. 1 a). After spin-unpolarized and spin-polarized geometry optimization, the atoms in metalloporphyrin rings for all TM-PDY systems are on the same plane with the TM-N bond distances ranging from 1.95 to 2.10 Å. The TM-PDY systems belong to the space group P4/mmm ( D 4 h 1 ) and the calculated lattice parameters are in the range of 22.10–22.23 Å. The stabilities of TM-PDY systems can be evaluated by computing the formation energy (Ef ) and the dissolution potential (Udiss ), based on the definitions: Ef = E TM-PDY - E PDY - E TM and U diss = U d i s s 0 (metal, bulk) - E f N e | e | , where E TM-PDY and E PDY denote the total energies of PDY with and without metal atom, E TM is the energy of the metal atom in the stable bulk phase, U d i s s 0 (metal, bulk) and Ne represent the standard dissolution of bulk metal and the number of transferred electron. As shown in Fig. 1c and Table S1, the values of Ef are in the range of −1.23 ∼ −6.44 eV. The negative values of Ef mean that the TM atoms are thermodynamically favorable to anchor on the PDY rather than diffusing or aggregating. The positive values of U diss (>0 V) manifest that the dissolution of TM atoms can be prevented under electrochemical conditions. As shown in the red zone in Fig. 1c, the considered catalysts are all with the negative Ef and positive U diss, exhibiting both thermodynamically and electrochemically stabilities. The Bader charge computations reveal that the plentiful electrons are transferred (0.75 to 1.76 |e|) from TM sites to PDY, making the TM atoms positively charged, which also implies the strong interactions between TM atoms and PDY (Fig. 1d and Table S1). The calculations of electronic properties indicate the band gaps of TM-PDY systems are in the range of 0.09–2.14 eV (Table S1). Additionally, most TM-PDY systems exhibit ferromagnetism with magnetic moments varying from 1.0 to 4.0 μ B , while Ni/Pt/Pd-PDY are nonmagnetism. 3.2 The OER/ORR catalytic activities of TM-PDY Based on the stable geometrical structures, we further evaluated the OER/ORR catalytic activities of TM-PDY by computing the adsorption Gibbs free energies of reaction intermediates (ΔG OH*, ΔG O, ΔG OOH*) on the catalysts. On the grounds of the Sabatier principle, only the moderate adsorption strengths between adsorbates and electrocatalysts can bring beneficial effects on the OER/ORR catalytic performances [58]. For the ideal OER/ORR catalysts, the adsorption Gibbs free energy difference of neighboring intermediates during the whole reactions should be 1.23 eV when U = 0 V and then the values of overpotential (η OER/η ORR) are 0 V. In reality, the η OER and η ORR can be obtained by calculating the maximum difference of adsorption Gibbs free energy for OER and ORR as presented in the Supporting information, which means the minimum voltage needed for driving the four-step OER and ORR reactions respectively. As the initial step for the OER process, the geometrical configurations with the OH group adsorbed on the positively charged TM atoms were optimized and the correlative ΔG OH* values for 15 TM-PDY systems were computed. It can be clearly observed in Fig. 1e that the ΔG OH* values show a trend of periodic change related to the position where the TM atoms are located in the periodic table of elements. In the same period, the more valence electrons, the more positive ΔG OH* values. TM-PDY (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Rh, Ir) systems firstly draw our attention, where the related ΔG OH* values are in the range of 0.70∼1.19 eV close to the ideal Gibbs free energy difference values of 1.23 eV as aforementioned. We then computed the free energy diagrams of OER and ORR for TM-PDY systems. As shown in Fig. 2 , the four electrocatalytic steps of OER for Mn, Fe, Co, Rh, and Ir-PDY systems were all upward when U = 0 V. The potential-determining steps (PDSs) for Mn/Fe/Co/Ir-PDY are the third step (O* → OOH*), while for Rh-PDY is the second step (OH* → O*). The corresponding maximum differences of adsorption Gibbs free energy (ΔG max) are 2.61, 2.62, 1.70, 1.68, and 1.57 eV. When the electrode potential of 1.23 V is applied, although some steps are exothermic, extra energy still needs to overcome the energy barriers with the OER overpotential (η OER) of 1.38, 1.39, 0.47, 0.45, 0.34 V for Mn/Fe/Co/Ir/Rh-PDY, respectively. Especially, the computed η OER values for Co/Ir/Rh-PDY are smaller than that of the art-of-state IrO2 (0.56 V) [59,60], manifesting their remarkable OER catalytic performances. While the other TM-PDY (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Os, Ru, Ni, Cu, Pd, Pt) systems for which the interactions between OH* and catalysts are either too strong or too weak show poor OER catalytic activities with the large η OER values in the range of 1.00 ∼ 2.22 V (Fig. 3 and S1). The ORR can be regarded as the reverse of the OER and the ORR catalytic performances are measured by computing the maximum differences of adsorption Gibbs free energy (ΔG max) between two adjacent reaction steps to obtain the ORR overpotential (η ORR). As displayed in the free energy profiles of Fig. 2, when U = 0 V, the four ORR elementary steps for Co/Ir/Rh-PDY which exhibit excellent OER catalytic performances are downward, indicating the electrocatalytic steps are exothermic and the ORR process for these systems are viable at zero potential [61-64]. The PDSs for Co-PDY are the formation from O2 to OOH* with the ΔG max of −0.54 eV, but for Ir/Rh-PDY are the protonation of OH to H2O with the ΔG max of −0.86 and −0.76 eV. When the equilibrium electrode potential (U = 1.23 V) is applied, the maximal values of adsorption Gibbs free energy change are 0.69, 0.37, 0.47 eV for Co/Ir/Rh-PDY, resulting in the η ORR value of 0.69, 0.37 and 0.47 V respectively. The Rh-PDY and Ir-PDY systems can exhibit considerably high ORR catalytic activities with smaller or comparable η ORR values to the well-known Pt catalysts (0.45 V) [65,66]. As shown in Fig. 3, -other TM-PDY (TM = Sc/Ti/V/Cr/Mn/Fe/CO/Ni/Cu/Ru/Pd/Os/Pt) systems exhibit large η ORR values ranging from 0.57 to 2.98, indicating the inert ORR catalytic activities. Based on the results mentioned above, we predicted that the Ir- and Rh-PDY can act as high-performance OER/ORR bifunctional electrocatalysts with an overpotential of 0.45/0.37 and 0.34/0.47 V respectively. 3.3 The OER/ORR activity origin of TM-PDY electrocatalysts To provide valuable guidelines for further designing efficient electrocatalysts, we conducted a series of mechanism analyses to uncover the OER/ORR catalytic activity origin. As previously mentioned, the OER/ORR catalytic activity of materials is closely related to the binding strengths of the oxygenated species (OH*, O*, and OOH*) on catalysts. To this end, we examined the relationship of the adsorption Gibbs free energies of the reaction intermediates for all TM-PDY systems. As shown in Fig. 4 a and 4b, there are obvious scaling relationships for ΔG OOH* vs ΔG OH* and ΔG O* and ΔG OH*, which can be expressed as: ΔG OOH* =0.94ΔG OH* + 3.08 (R2 = 0.97) and ΔG O* = 1.39ΔG OH* + 0.85 (R2 = 0.83). The higher determination coefficient means the stronger linear relations between ΔG OH* and ΔG OOH*, which can be attributed to the similar bond character of TM-OH and TM-OOH. The ideal electrocatalysts should present moderate binding strength to reaction species (OH*, O* and OOH*) with ΔG OH* = 1.23 eV and ΔG OOH* = 3.69 eV [67], respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, the ΔG OH* and ΔG OOH* values for Sc/Ti-PDY are distinctly smaller than those of ideal catalysts due to the stronger adsorption of the OH* and OOH* species, resulting the inert OER/ORR catalytic activities. Poor catalytic activities have also been found on Pd-PDY on account of the weak binding strengths of the intermediates reflected by the larger values of ΔG OH* and ΔG OOH* than the ideal one. The Co, Ir and Rh anchored PDY for which the adsorption Gibbs free energies of OH* and OOH* are near the ideal model can possess satisfied OER or ORR catalytic performances. By substituting the linear relation ΔG OOH* =0.94ΔG OH* + 3.08 into Eqs S2-S5, the free energy changes of four steps can be further expressed as: (1) Δ G a = Δ G O H * (2) Δ G b = Δ G O * − Δ G O H * (3) Δ G c = ( 0.94 Δ G O H * + 3.08 ) − Δ G O * = − 0.06 Δ G O H * − ( Δ G O * − Δ G O H * ) + 3.08 (4) Δ G d = − 0.94 Δ G O H * + 1.84 Based on Eqs (1)-4, the values of ΔG O*-ΔG OH* and ΔG OH* can serve as descriptors to evaluate the OER and ORR catalytic activities of catalysts, respectively. The volcano plot was established by combining the values of η OER with ΔG O*-ΔG OH*. As shown in Fig. 4c, Co, Ir and Rh anchored PDY are located at the top position of the volcano with the η OER values ranging from 0.34 to 0.47 V, which verifies that the three candidates exhibit superior OER catalytic performance. Some TM anchored systems situated at the left side of the curve, such as V-PDY and Ti-PDY, implying that the binding strength of O* species is strong. While there are still some candidates laying on the right side of the plot owning to the weak O bonding. Besides, another volcano curve was acquired by considering the relationship of η ORR and ΔG OH* (Fig. 4d). The peak of the volcano plot was taken up by Ir-PDY and Rh-PDY at the ΔG OH* value of about 0.86 eV with the η ORR in the range of 0.37–0.47 eV, indicating the two samples exhibit high ORR catalytic performance. When the ΔG OH* for TM anchored PDY is <0.86 eV, the candidates are situated in the left part of the volcano plot, such as Sc-PDY and Ti-PDY, manifesting the strong OH binding on PDY. When the ΔG OH* is larger than 0.86 eV, the samples fell on the right part of the curve due to weak binding of OH, such as Cu-PDY. Besides, the PDSs of OER and ORR for TM-PDY are marked in Figs. 4c and d. The step 3 (O* → OOH*) and step 1 (H2O → OH*) are the main PDSs for OER, except for Sc, Ti (step 4: OOH* → O2) and Rh (step 2: OH* → O*). While for ORR, step 4 (OH* → H2O) and step 1 (O2→ OOH*) become main PDSs, apart from Mn and Fe (step 3: O* → OH*). The two-dimensional (2D) contour maps of OER and ORR are presented in Fig. 4e and 4f by visualizing overpotentials as a function of the values of ΔG O*-ΔG OH* and ΔG OH*. The overpotentials of all TM-PDY systems are characterized by graduated colors. The red regions in the two contour maps are the optimal catalytic performance parts with smaller overpotentials for OER and ORR, respectively. Both the maps are divided into four parts utilizing borderlines which are obtained by solving Eqs (1)-4 in conjunction. The four zones represent the free energy changes of four elementary reaction steps and also mean the corresponding PDSs for OER and ORR. As shown in Fig. 4e, the Rh, Co, and Ir-PDY systems which are near the borderline between step 2 and step 3 exhibit considerably high OER catalytic activities with small overpotentials (0.34, 0.47, and 0.45 V). In addition, Ir and Rh-PDY are located at the junction of step 1 and step 4 in Fig. 4f, verifying that they are ideal ORR catalysts. To clarify the inherent factors of the catalytic performance, we performed a series of electronic properties investigations utilizing the d-band center theory and the projected crystal orbital Hamilton populations (pCOHP). We calculated the d-band center (ε d) of all the TM-PDY candidates from the corresponding partial density of states (PDOS), which can be viewed as an available descriptor for adsorption free energy of intermediate species on the catalytic substrates, as depicted in Fig. 5 a and S2. Generally, the ε d value shifts to a more negative part as the number of d-electron increases in the same period. For example, the ε d values for 3d TM follow the trend: Sc (0.09) > Ti (0.08) > Cr (−0.51) > Mn (−1.01) > Fe (−1.03) > Co (−1.29) > Ni (−2.53) > Cu (−3.21), except for V (0.3). The different ε d can lead to different adsorption strengths of reaction intermediates. Generally, a more negative ε d is closely associated with weaker binding. The reason is that the hybridization between TM-d and O-2p orbital will form the bonding and antibonding states. The more negative ε d makes the antibonding orbital highly occupied by electrons, thus decreasing the interaction strength. The negative relationship between ε d and the Gibbs free energy of oxygenated species can be obtained in Fig. 5a. Moreover, we also explore the pCOHP of TM-OH for all anchored systems, where the positive and negative contributions of COHP signify the antibonding (i.e., left) and bonding states (i.e., right), respectively (Figure S3). For Ir/Rh-PDY, the increased filling of the antibonding orbital population in valence bands (below Fermi energy) weakens the adsorption strength of OH* on catalysts, which is favorable to enhance the catalytic performance. By integrating the COHP up to the Fermi level (ICOHP) of OH* intermediates, a strong linear correlation is established between ICOHP and ΔG OH* with a determination coefficient (R2) of 0.94 (Fig. 5b). A more negative value of ICOHP means a stronger adsorption strength. In general, the bonding strength gradually decreases as the number of electrons increases in the same period (Fig. 5b). The linear relations in Fig. 5a and 5b (ε d vs. ΔG OH*, ICOHP vs. ΔG OH*) demonstrate that the d-band center and ICOHP can serve as descriptors to quantitatively describe the adsorption strength and reveal that the catalytic activity derives from the electronic structures. In addition, a universal descriptor (φ) is introduced to predict the OER/ORR catalytic performance from the perspective of local structure and chemical environment of active sites [68,69], which is expressed as: φ = θ d × χ a v e r χ o , where θ d denotes the valence electron number of TM atom, χO represents the electronegativity of the O atom, and χaver is the average electronegativity of TM atom and N atoms attached it. χaver can be defined as χ a v e r = ( χ TM + 4 χ N ) / 5 in this work, where χTM and χN stand for the electronegativities of TM atoms and their attached N atoms. As shown in Fig. 5c, it can be found that the descriptor φ and ΔG OH* exhibit obvious linear correlation via the expression of ΔG OH* = 0.63φ – 3.37 with R2 of 0.85, confirming that the adsorption free energies are closely related to the local surrounding of active centers. The ΔG OH* of the ideal catalyst is 1.23 eV and the corresponding φ is 7.3. The φ values for Ir and Rh-PDY with excellent OER/ORR bifunctional catalytic activities range from 7.51 to 7.56 which are around the optimal area. The structure descriptor φ can be acquired from known information without complex calculation, thus providing a high-efficiency way to design electrocatalysts. 4 Conclusion In this work, we performed a comprehensive DFT investigation on structures, stabilities, OER and ORR catalytic properties on a variety of 2D metalloporphyrin-based GDY. Our results showed that Ir and Rh-PDY exhibit high-performance OER and ORR catalytic performance with the low η OER and η ORR (0.45/0.37 and 0.34/0.47 V), which are potential bifunctional catalysts. The explorations of inherent factors of catalysts, including ε d, ICOHP, and φ, reveal the origin of OER and ORR catalytic activities. Our study not only develops a new application field of 2D metalloporphyrin-based COFs but also offers a new method to construct satisfactory catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Metalloporphyrin-based covalent organic frameworks (COFs) with controllable metal sites and charge densities have become a front research field in catalysis. Herein, through the comprehensive density functional theory (DFT) computations, we explored the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalytic activities on a series of two-dimensional (2D) metalloporphyrin-based graphdiyne analogs (TM-PDY, TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, Pt), which are constructed by connecting metal coordinated 5,10,15,20-tetra-(4-phenyl)porphyrin rings and butadiyne. The computations show that Ir- and Rh-PDY can serve as outstanding bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER and ORR with ultralow overpotentials (0.45/0.37 and 0.34/0.47 V). The excellent catalytic behaviors are derived from the moderate adsorption interaction of oxygenated species as revealed by the scaling relationships and volcano curves. Remarkably, the adsorption free energies of intermediates are highly related to the electronic structures of TM-PDYs, characterized by the d-band center (ε d), the integrating crystal orbital Hamilton populations (ICOHP), and the universal descriptor φ. Our work not only reveals the OER and ORR catalytic performance of TM-PDYs but also provides an instructive strategy to design catalysts for the energy conversation and storage devices.
